update.description:
A camera sensor plugin that publishes the image coordinates of all fiducials detected in the image

a fiducial model is detected only when ~~~a) it's bounding box is within the camera frustum, and b)~~~ its center point is not occluded by other models in the camera view.

added an example `fiducial` world to demo the sensor plugin

jenkins:

[homebrew](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/main/view/CI%20any%20jobs/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/490/) - ok
update.title: Add FiducialCameraPlugin for Camera Sensors

content.raw: Issue #2001

content.raw:
A plugin would report the location of fiducials, either by directly analyzing the pixels or using opencv. This approach would also let other people use opencv (or some other image processing library) to identify fiducials. The material properties for each fiducial could have a different color.

I'll make a feature request for this.
content.html:
A plugin would report the location of fiducials, either by directly analyzing the pixels or using opencv. This approach would also let other people use opencv (or some other image processing library) to identify fiducials. The material properties for each fiducial could have a different color.

I'll make a feature request for this.

content.html: ya both approaches are fine. I just made them class members to avoid the get function calls on every update.

done. 91c5243

I had the idea to make another plugin that derives from `FiducialCameraPlugin` and override the `Publish` function for application-specific use cases. But I don't think it's necessary now - I can just get the data by subscribing to the fiducial topic.
content.html:
done. 91c5243

I had the idea to make another plugin that derives from FiducialCameraPlugin and override the Publish function for application-specific use cases. But I don't think it's necessary now - I can just get the data by subscribing to the fiducial topic.

content.raw:
Ya I agree that making a new IR camera sensor will be more efficient than using the camera sensor and doing more processing in the plugin. 

A question about the proposed approach - how does the sensor identify the fiducials? Will it iterate over the image to find the location of white pixels? Each fiducial needs to be unique so the objects need to have different colors. So It's kind of like what selection buffer is doing?
content.html:
Ya I agree that making a new IR camera sensor will be more efficient than using the camera sensor and doing more processing in the plugin.

A question about the proposed approach - how does the sensor identify the fiducials? Will it iterate over the image to find the location of white pixels? Each fiducial needs to be unique so the objects need to have different colors. So It's kind of like what selection buffer is doing?

content.html: Do you want to add correct inertial properties to this model and the next model?

content.html:

I don't think this function needs to be public, correct?

content.raw:
Could also just pass the pointers into PopulateFiducials(), rather than setting them in both the parent and child calls.

(Unless of course, the plan for later expansion would favour class members.)
content.html:
Could also just pass the pointers into PopulateFiducials(), rather than setting them in both the parent and child calls.

(Unless of course, the plan for later expansion would favour class members.)

content.raw:
Alternative implementation thought:

1. Create a new material that renders an object white if it is a fiducial, and black otherwise.
1. Apply the material to fiducials.
1. Create a new IR camera sensor that renders the scene using the fiducial material.
1. Crete a plugin the publishes the location of each visible fiducial.

This approach is a major departure from this PR. However, it would probably be more efficient. 

Time being what it is; we can move this idea to a feature request. Just wanted to collect thoughts on the approach.
content.html:
Alternative implementation thought:

  1. Create a new material that renders an object white if it is a fiducial, and black otherwise.
  2. Apply the material to fiducials.
  3. Create a new IR camera sensor that renders the scene using the fiducial material.
  4. Crete a plugin the publishes the location of each visible fiducial.

This approach is a major departure from this PR. However, it would probably be more efficient.

Time being what it is; we can move this idea to a feature request. Just wanted to collect thoughts on the approach.

content.raw: Can `camera` and `scene` be made class members?
content.html: Can camera and scene be made class members?

content.raw: looks like I had the wrong understanding of the `Camera::IsVisible` functionality. Objects that are partially visible are also returned as visible. I've added some comments in the plugin's doxygen to describe the expected behavior. 3b72055
content.html: looks like I had the wrong understanding of the Camera::IsVisible functionality. Objects that are partially visible are also returned as visible. I've added some comments in the plugin's doxygen to describe the expected behavior. 3b72055

content.raw: Optional request: It would be nice to allow another boolean parameter in the plugin `filter_all` or similar that reports all the objects within the FOV and not occluded. Maybe there are use cases where you don't know in advance the objects that you want to filter.
content.html: Optional request: It would be nice to allow another boolean parameter in the plugin filter_all or similar that reports all the objects within the FOV and not occluded. Maybe there are use cases where you don't know in advance the objects that you want to filter.

content.raw: What's the difference between the logicalCameraSensor and the FiducialCameraPlugin? The logicalCamera doesn't require to render the scene but on the other hand it doesn't take into account occlusions? It seems also that the user needs to specify the fiducials that are going to pass the filter. Am I right?
content.html: What's the difference between the logicalCameraSensor and the FiducialCameraPlugin? The logicalCamera doesn't require to render the scene but on the other hand it doesn't take into account occlusions? It seems also that the user needs to specify the fiducials that are going to pass the filter. Am I right?
